body.body: Bornholm Dictionary provides unified access to a number of Bornholm glossaries and other resources, including Bornholm-language texts. The dictionary belongs to the Institute of Nordic Studies and Linguistics (NorS) at the University of Copenhagen and has been created in collaboration with a large number of volunteers ( on the project and its history, see this page). The dictionary is a meta dictionary that combines a series of glossaries into one database, so that from one search you can look up all of them and get a complete result with relevant articles from all glossaries, which contains the keyword. The majority of the material has not been previously released

body.heading: Newton's Laws of Motion
body.body: Newton's laws describe the relationship between a body and the forces acting upon it.

body.heading: Kinematics
body.body: Kinematics deals with the motion of objects without considering the forces causing the motion.

body.heading: Properties of Waves
body.body: Waves exhibit properties like amplitude, frequency, and wavelength.

body.heading: Geometrical Optics
body.body: Geometrical optics studies light propagation using the laws of reflection and refraction.

body.heading: Sumerians and City-States
body.body: The Sumerians developed the concept of city-states and made significant advancements in writing.

body.heading: Babylon and Hammurabi's Code
body.body: Babylon became a major power under Hammurabi, known for his famous legal code.

body.heading: Nile River and Agriculture
body.body: The Nile River played a crucial role in the development of Egyptian agriculture and culture.

body.heading: Pyramids and Pharaohs
body.body: Pyramids were monumental tombs built for pharaohs and symbolized their power.

body.heading: Variables and Data Types
body.body: Variables store data, and data types define the nature of that data.

body.heading: Control Structures
body.body: Control structures like loops and conditionals govern the flow of a program.

body.heading: Classes and Objects
body.body: Classes define the structure of objects, which are instances of a class.

body.heading: Inheritance and Polymorphism
body.body: Inheritance allows new classes to inherit attributes and methods from existing classes.

body.heading: The Mind-Body Connection
body.body: Psychology explores the intricate relationship between the mind and the body.

body.heading: Conscious vs. Unconscious Mind
body.body: Psychologists study the interplay between conscious and unconscious mental processes.

body.heading: Psychoanalytic Theory
body.body: Sigmund Freud's psychoanalytic theory delves into the subconscious aspects of personality.

body.heading: Humanistic Approach
body.body: Humanistic psychologists focus on personal growth, self-actualization, and fulfillment.

body.heading: Ecological Relationships
body.body: Ecosystems are comprised of various organisms that interact in complex ways.

body.heading: Conservation of Biodiversity
body.body: Preserving biodiversity is crucial for ecological stability and human well-being.

body.heading: Global Warming and Greenhouse Gases
body.body: Human activities have led to an increase in greenhouse gases, contributing to climate change.

body.heading: Sustainable Practices
body.body: Promoting sustainability involves adopting practices that minimize environmental impact.

body.heading: Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy
body.body: Jane Austen's novel follows the evolving relationship between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy.

body.heading: Society and Marriage
body.body: The novel explores societal norms and expectations surrounding marriage.

body.heading: Pip's Journey
body.body: Charles Dickens' story traces Pip's transformation from a humble boy to a gentleman.

body.heading: Social Class and Identity
body.body: The novel examines the impact of social class on characters' identities and destinies.
